description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Extent to which climate finance is being accessed (by government and non-government institutions)
Extent to which there is a strengthened system in place to access, deliver, monitor, report on and verify climate finance
Extent to which implementation of comprehensive measures - plans, strategies, policies, programmes and budgets - to achieve low-emission and climate-resilient development objectives has improved.
Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women
Total number of people with improved access to energy as a result of UNDP-supported intervention
percentage of households benefitting from improved energy access which are female headed households
Systematic Energy Management in Public Sector Buildings in Croatia - Technical assistance to local communties

description.narrative: number of rural households with newly enabled access to electricity

comment.narrative: - 2005. At the time of starting the UNDP-GEF EE Project six years ago (in 2006), there was an incomplete legal framework in the area of energy efficiency in Croatia. There were insufficient human and technical resources for energy management in the public sector, the majority of data regarding buildings owned or used by cities, counties and ministries were incomplete, and provided no information on energy consumption and the cost of thereof. There was a general absence of energy management in buildings, insufficient awareness of energy efficiency as an energy source, and inadequate knowledge on energy efficient products and technologies. - 2013: There are still rural households in Croatia with no electricity access. Some analysis show that there are approximately 126 villages with more than 500 houses of mostly war returnees that are not connected to the public electricity grid.

Work on partnerships with regional government and financial institutions to ensure electrification of 50 rural households, bringing electricity to approximately 100 inhabitants who are living in households throughout the entire year. Installation of photo voltaic systems into households.

In 46 households photo voltaic systems (PV1000, PV1500 ili PV3000) with batteries has been installed and functional. Systems enable households to perform everyday activities (lighting of the space, use of the house appliances, use of TV/radio, use of other electric devices). Households are additionally equipped with the LED light bulbs, energy efficient refrigerators and aggregates. Whole project was co-financed (in highest part) by the Environment Protection and Energy Efficiency Fund, and the local/regional government. Price of installed systems is up to 10 times cheaper than a traditional solution through national electricity grid extension.

description.narrative: The overall project idea of low-emission development (LED) is to address climate change in Croatia by shifting towards low-carbon development that offers substantial opportunities and ensures continued high growth and sustainable development, based on the Low Emission Development Strategy (hereafter LEDS). LEDS aims at reducing greenhouse gas emissions, environmental protection, stimulating economic growth through sustainability, creating opportunities for new jobs and guiding society towards long-term sustainable development. description.narrative: Low-emission development strategy for Croatia prepared Technical and instituitonal capacities increased through different pilot-projects that demostrate low-carbon development in practice

comment.narrative: Weak technical and institutional capacities that are able to plan for and to create a roadmap for low-carbon and climate resilient development of Croatia. There is no low-emission development strategy for Croatia.

Development of innovative portfolio of projects related to sustainable energy solutions. Building capacities in public sector for green public procurement. Citizenergy crowdfunding platform with target of 50 projects to be on the platform.

The Low-carbon development team worked on an innovative portfolio of projects related to sustainable energy solutions: supporting energy cooperatives, programme of energy advisors for energy-poor households, building capacities in public sector for green public procurement with more then 30 green tenders and on-line helpdesk transferred to the Ministry of Environment. “WE Engage” Toolkit was designed to help all stakeholders to build and deliver effective social engagement strategies fornshore wind farms; on testing models for community-financing of renewable energy via crowdfunding and crowd-investing at the EU level. Citisenergy platform has been put together with targeted 50 projects to be on the platform. Current status is 21 platforms + 28 projects at 11 countries with €21,888,281 invested into renewable energy installations through crowdfunding model.
Finalization and wrap up of project activities and results. (Project to be closed in Q1 2017)

The Low-carbon development project was active only in the first quarter of 2017. Project team worked on finalization and reporting of project activities and transfer of knowledge to partners institutions. In 2017 activities were mostly focused on CITIZENERGY sub-project, where Evaluation of new implemented projects was produced as the conclusion of the Croatian team results. At the beginning of February 2017 there were 41 energy projects registered in the Citizenergy crowdfunding platform, from 11 countries and 16 RES promoters. Community energy projects are in different stages of development in 41 locations in 15 countries. Study Tour "Energy Cooperatives in Croatia" was organized in partnership with GIZ and ZEZ.
